" DATATABLE.700,2014-02-25T16:17:04.908,2014-02-25T16:17:04.908,125.57815099999993,-8.558458,Timor-Leste,Dili,,"Timor Leste Building and Construction Expo 2014 August 11-13, 2014",,Construction,1000,"Timor Leste is experiencing rapid economic and infrastructure development offering great potential for private sector investment. The Government of Timor Leste is committed to infrastructure development, which is reflected by a significant budget allocation. There is a need to build and upgrade the majority of the country’s infrastructure, in particular roads and bridges, sea- and airports. Moreover, the Government of Timor Leste embarked on a major patroleum industry development including for example a supply base and a refinery. Aside from these major developments, significant resources from the government, donors and the private sector keep flowing towards construction or rehabilitation of government offices, housing, schools, hospitals as well as the development of tourism resorts or shopping malls. Business opportunities are thus abundent, in particular with regards to building materials, construction equipment, extractives-driven industrial construction and transport infrastructure. The Government of Timor-Leste plans to allocate over US$ 868 million to its infrastructure fund in 2014 – this is consitent with what has been spent/allocated in 2012 and 2013 as part of the infrastructure fund. Major items of the infrastructure fund are: • US$ 173.9 million allocated to improve electricity generation, transmition and distribution • US$ 139.4 million allocated to develop three industrial clusters on the South Coast which will form the backbone of Timor Leste’s petroleum industry (Tasi Mane Project). Tasi Mane includes the Suai Supply Base Cluster, the Betano Refinery and Petrochemical Industry Cluster, and the Beaco LNG-Plant Cluster. • US$ 156.8 million allocated to roads, bridges, port and airport. In addition to the Infrastructure Fund, each ministry as budget allocations for smaller infrastructure projects, amounting to approximately US$ 140 million. THE TRADE FAIR Spread over three to four days, the event is the ideal forum for international players in the industry to showcase products and services to Timor Leste businesses. Over 4,000 companies in Timor Leste will be invited to interact with the representatives of the exhibiting companies personally. ","Trade Expo, construction, infrastructure",Post Identified Project,2014-02-25,2014-08-11,Government,None,Government of Timor-Leste,"Julia Baptista Leite, Info@iade.gov.tl",,Shawn Baxter,BaxterGS@state.gov,http://www.iade.gov.tl/tet/legals/kompetisaun-plano-negosiu/,http://timor-leste.usembassy.gov/business.html,,,1,In Procurement,1,POINT (13979295.824080812 -956285.9976222),"
Timor Leste Building and Construction Expo 2014 August 11-13, 2014
Country: Timor-Leste
Sector: Construction
Date Added: 2014-02-25
Primary Funding Source: Government
Project Size (USD): 1000
Status: In Procurement

Archived: Yes
Description:
Timor Leste is experiencing rapid economic and infrastructure development offering great potential for private sector investment. The Government of Timor Leste is committed to infrastructure development, which is reflected by a significant budget allocation. There is a need to build and upgrade the majority of the country’s infrastructure, in particular roads and bridges, sea- and airports. Moreover, the Government of Timor Leste embarked on a major patroleum industry development including for example a supply base and a refinery. Aside from these major developments, significant resources from the government, donors and the private sector keep flowing towards construction or rehabilitation of government offices, housing, schools, hospitals as well as the development of tourism resorts or shopping malls. Business opportunities are thus abundent, in particular with regards to building materials, construction equipment, extractives-driven industrial construction and transport infrastructure. The Government of Timor-Leste plans to allocate over US$ 868 million to its infrastructure fund in 2014 – this is consitent with what has been spent/allocated in 2012 and 2013 as part of the infrastructure fund. Major items of the infrastructure fund are: • US$ 173.9 million allocated to improve electricity generation, transmition and distribution • US$ 139.4 million allocated to develop three industrial clusters on the South Coast which will form the backbone of Timor Leste’s petroleum industry (Tasi Mane Project). Tasi Mane includes the Suai Supply Base Cluster, the Betano Refinery and Petrochemical Industry Cluster, and the Beaco LNG-Plant Cluster. • US$ 156.8 million allocated to roads, bridges, port and airport. In addition to the Infrastructure Fund, each ministry as budget allocations for smaller infrastructure projects, amounting to approximately US$ 140 million. THE TRADE FAIR Spread over three to four days, the event is the ideal forum for international players in the industry to showcase products and services to Timor Leste businesses. Over 4,000 companies in Timor Leste will be invited to interact with the representatives of the exhibiting companies personally.

Post Comments:


Project Website   Embassy Website   Contact
" DATATABLE.894,2014-08-19T10:27:56.394,2014-08-19T10:27:56.394,34.98957100000007,32.7940463,Israel,Haifa,,Construction of the New Cargo Gate Area in the Port of Haifa,12/5054/07/12 ,Construction,100000,"1. The Tender will be conducted as a two -stage process, in accordance with the Tenders Law of the State of Israel, 5753 – 1993. The IPC shall be entitle, but not obligated, at is sole discretion to conduct negotiation, or to select the winner on the basis of proposals as submitted in the Tender documents, and shall be entitled to cancel the tender process. 2. Scope of Work: 2.1 The Works consist of the construction of a gate area for the entrance and exit of cargo-carrying trucks for the Port of Haifa. The works will be carried out on an area of about 120 dunams (about 120,000 m²), most of the works will be carried out in the Port area, while the rest of the works will be carried out on Vilbush Street (in the city). 2.2 The Works include, among other matters: Infrastructure and asphalt works, area development, construction of temporary and permanent buildings, steel works, fencing, gates and barriers, electrical and communications infrastructure works, electrical works, lighting and communications works, a system for water supply and fire-fighting, and sewage works. 2.3 Note that the works subject to the tender work will be performed in parallel with installation of technology equipment at the gate by other contractor/s. The winning contractor will be required full coordination with such contractor/s. 3. The Duration of the Project: approximately 3 years. 4. Participation in the Tender is conditioned upon the following threshold conditions: 4.1 The registration of the Bidder with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the tender, in Branch 200 – Roads, Infrastructure and Development, Classification ""Gimel"" – 5 (Unlimited). A Foreign Bidder must present an exemption from such Classification from the Registrar of Contractors no later than three calendar months after the notice of the award to the Foreign Bidder – as a precondition to the signing of the contract in the event that the foreign contractor is awarded the works.. 4.2 The presentation of a Bid Security (Bid Bond) in the form of an unconditional Bank Guarantee, for the payment of all amounts up to 4,000,000 New Israeli Shekels (NIS) as demanded by the IPC in connection with this tender and which will be in force until 23/3/2015. A Foreign Bidder may present an unconditional Bank Guarantee, written only in the English language, for the payment of all amounts up to $1,150,000 US or 840,000 Euro, from a bank which is rated with an international rating of at least A for Foreign Currency by S&P or with an equivalent rating from another rating agency. The Bank must be located in a nation which has diplomatic relations with the State of Israel (hereby ""Approved bank""). The Bank guarantee will explicitly specify that it is for ""Tender No. 12/5054/07/12 – Construction of the New Cargo Gate Area in the Port of Haifa"" (The IPC shall be entitled to demand an extension of the period of this Bank Guarantee for a period of an additional six months). 4.3 The presentation by Israeli entities of all certificates, affidavits and approvals in accordance with the Transactions by Public Bodies (Enforcement of Keeping of Accounts) Law, 5736-1976. In the event that the Bidder which is awarded the Works is a non-Israeli entity, and as a condition precedent to the signing of the Contract with the non-Israeli entity, payments to that non-Israeli entity will be made through a local, Israeli, company which will be established by the non-Israeli entity. The local – Israeli – company must present all certificates, affidavits and approvals in accordance with the Transactions by Public Bodies (Enforcement of Keeping of Accounts) Law, 5736-1976. as a condition precedent to the signing of the contract with the non-Israeli entity 4.4 Proven experience of the Bidder, as a main contractor, in carrying out paving and area development projects, with at least two projects that were carried out since the year 2003 onward and completed, and which the payments for the performance of paving and area development works included in them were of at least 25,000,000 NIS for each such project. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax.) 4.5 The Bidder, or a subcontractor proposed by the Bidder for performance of the communication infrastructures, must meet all of the following conditions: 4.5.1 Registration with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the Tender, in Branch 240 – Laying of Communications Cables, of at least Classification ""Alef"" – 1. 4.5.2 Proven experience in the design, supply, installation and support of communications infrastructure projects, with at least two projects , since 2006 onwards with each one of them being of at least 1,000,000 NIS. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS is in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax.) 4.5.3 Possessing a valid and existing license for network termination points from the Ministry of Communications. 4.5.4 The Bidder, or a subcontractor proposed by the Bidder, for carrying out the electrical works must meet all of the following conditions: 4.5.4.1 Registration with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the Tender, in Branch 160 – Electrical Works, of Classification ""Alef"" – 5 (unlimited). 4.5.4.2 Proven experience performing electrical work at low voltages and high voltage and has performed, from 2006 onwards, at least one project of electrical work including low and high voltage works, amounting to at least 10 million NIS. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax. 4.6 For the purpose of demonstrating the financial stability of the Bidder, the Bidder shall present a certification, from its bank, updated as of a date one month before the last date which has been fixed for presentation of the Tender, in accordance with the text set out in Document ""P"" of the Tender Documents. A Foreign Bidder may present a letter from an ""Approved bank"". A Bank letter which contains material changes in the text and which are not changes just in style, in accordance with the discretion of the Bid Committee, will not be accepted. 4.7 Participation in a Site Visit for potential Bidders/contractors that shall take place on27/8/2014 beginning at 10:00 and which will depart from the Port's club, at the security building, in the Haifa Port. Those interested in participating in the Site Visit must send a written request, no later than 20/8/2014 at 14:00 to Fax +972-3-5622173. The request must include the name(s) of the participant(s), their Identity Numbers or their Passport Number (with a copy of the relevant identification page(s) from their Passport) and the license plate number of the participant(s) car. For a further explanation with regard to the location of the conference and Site Visit, please contact the Project Manager, Engineer Chaim Ziv, at +972-52-329-0505. It is hereby emphasized that all Bidders must participate in the site visit. Only those Bidders who participated in the site visit will be permitted to submit their tenders for these Works. 5. The Tender Documents: 5.1 The Tender Documents, which are in Hebrew, can be reviewed , without charge, beginning on 12/8/2014, at the offices of the IPC, Menachem Begin Road 74, Tel Aviv, 10 th floor, Room 1003 on Sunday through Thursday, between the hours of 9:00 until 14:00. 5.2 The Tender Documents, which are in Hebrew, can be purchased at the offices mentioned in paragraph 5.1 and on the days and times set out therein, for the non-refundable sum of 1,500 NIS, including VAT which shall be paid to at the Treasurer's Office of the IPC 5.3 In addition to that which is set out in paragraph 5.2, a Potential Bidder which wants to participate in the Tender is required to pay to the IPC, before presenting its Tender, a participation fee of the non-refundable sum of 13,500 NIS, including VAT. This fee must be paid at the Treasurer's Department of the IPC or must be deposited in the bank account of the IPC at ""Bank Hapoalim"" Branch 063, Account no.7517. 6. For foreign Bidders, the above-mentioned sums in NIS shall be calculated on the basis of 4.8 NIS for 1 Euro or 3.5 NIS for 1 U.S. Dollar, except the amount of the Bid Security (Bid Bond). 7. Those interested in participating in the Tender must submit their Tenders in writing, with all the required documentation, in a sealed envelope, no later than 23/9/2014, at 12:00 in the Tender Box in the Offices of the IPC, 74 Menachem Begin Road, Tel Aviv, Israel, 10th floor, Room 1010. 8. The IPC is not obligated to accept the least expensive Tendered offer or any Tendered offer whatsoever. 9. Additional information can be received from the Head of the Construction Department of the IPC, TEL +972 - (3)-5657922, FAX +972 (3)-5616541. Those making inquiries by fax should request verification of the receipt of any such inquiries. 10. This advertisement does not contain all of the Tender Conditions. The entire and binding Tender Conditions appear in the Tender Documents. Thus, in the event of any discrepancy between this advertisement and the Tender Documents, that which is stated in the Tender Documents shall prevail . It is hereby clarified that the binding version of the Tender Documents are those in the Hebrew language. 11. All of a Bidder's expenses and costs, of any type whatsoever, which are connected with the preparation of and/or participation in the Tender, shall be borne by the Bidder only and, in any event, will not be returned to it. 12. Mandatory Business Cooperation A Foreign Bidder - in the event it wins the Tender – is obligated to provide Business Cooperation at a level of 35% of the Contract Price if it is an entity not from a Nation which is a party to the Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) or at a level of 20% if it is an entity from a Nation which is a party to the GPA, all in accordance with the Mandatory Tenders Regulations (Preferences for Israel Products and Business Cooperation) 5755 – 1995, to the extent that the Regulations do not contradict the obligations of the State of Israel under any international treaty. 13. Conditions : It is brought to the attention of all Bidders that the performance of these works is subject to the precondition of the receipt of all appropriate permits and budgetary approvals and that all decisions about the winner of the Tender and/or contracting with that winning Bidder will be subject to the precondition, as above said, and will not enter into force unless these preconditions are met. The period of time for the carrying out of these preconditions will be up to 4 months after the date of the signing of a Contract with the winner of this Tender. Everyone presenting an offer in this Tender does it with knowledge of these preconditions and agrees to waive all claims with regard to these preconditions. Everyone presenting an offer agrees, in presenting its offer, that it has not obtained any rights in the event that a condition is not met and/or that it will not be possible to carry out the Works in accordance with this Tender (whether there has been a contract between the IPC and it or not), and that it will not be entitled to any damages or indemnification or return of sums whatsoever. In such an event, the contract which will be signed with the winner of the Tender will be a conditional contract subject to the receipt of all legally-required permits and authorizations. In any event, it is hereby emphasized that the contract between the IPC and the winning Bidder will enter into effect just if the above conditions are met. ","Haifa, Construction, Port, Cargo Gate, Israel",Post Identified Project,2014-08-11,2014-09-23,Government,Government of Israel,Port of Haif," Additional information can be received from the Head of the Construction Department of the IPC, TEL +972 - (3)-5657922, FAX +972 (3)-5616541. Those making inquiries by fax should request verification of the receipt of any such inquiries.",Please contact Charles Brown at US Embassy Tel Aviv for more information,Charles Brown,browncl3@state.gov,http://eng.israports.co.il/PortsDevelop/internationaltender/Pages/ConstructionoftheNewCargoGateAreainthePortofHaifa.aspx,http://israel.usembassy.gov/business.html,,,1,In Procurement,0,POINT (3895021.2267950997 3867998.852946981),"
Construction of the New Cargo Gate Area in the Port of Haifa
Country: Israel
Sector: Construction
Date Added: 2014-08-19
Primary Funding Source: Government
Project Size (USD): 100000
Status: In Procurement

Description:
1. The Tender will be conducted as a two -stage process, in accordance with the Tenders Law of the State of Israel, 5753 – 1993. The IPC shall be entitle, but not obligated, at is sole discretion to conduct negotiation, or to select the winner on the basis of proposals as submitted in the Tender documents, and shall be entitled to cancel the tender process. 2. Scope of Work: 2.1 The Works consist of the construction of a gate area for the entrance and exit of cargo-carrying trucks for the Port of Haifa. The works will be carried out on an area of about 120 dunams (about 120,000 m²), most of the works will be carried out in the Port area, while the rest of the works will be carried out on Vilbush Street (in the city). 2.2 The Works include, among other matters: Infrastructure and asphalt works, area development, construction of temporary and permanent buildings, steel works, fencing, gates and barriers, electrical and communications infrastructure works, electrical works, lighting and communications works, a system for water supply and fire-fighting, and sewage works. 2.3 Note that the works subject to the tender work will be performed in parallel with installation of technology equipment at the gate by other contractor/s. The winning contractor will be required full coordination with such contractor/s. 3. The Duration of the Project: approximately 3 years. 4. Participation in the Tender is conditioned upon the following threshold conditions: 4.1 The registration of the Bidder with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the tender, in Branch 200 – Roads, Infrastructure and Development, Classification ""Gimel"" – 5 (Unlimited). A Foreign Bidder must present an exemption from such Classification from the Registrar of Contractors no later than three calendar months after the notice of the award to the Foreign Bidder – as a precondition to the signing of the contract in the event that the foreign contractor is awarded the works.. 4.2 The presentation of a Bid Security (Bid Bond) in the form of an unconditional Bank Guarantee, for the payment of all amounts up to 4,000,000 New Israeli Shekels (NIS) as demanded by the IPC in connection with this tender and which will be in force until 23/3/2015. A Foreign Bidder may present an unconditional Bank Guarantee, written only in the English language, for the payment of all amounts up to $1,150,000 US or 840,000 Euro, from a bank which is rated with an international rating of at least A for Foreign Currency by S&P or with an equivalent rating from another rating agency. The Bank must be located in a nation which has diplomatic relations with the State of Israel (hereby ""Approved bank""). The Bank guarantee will explicitly specify that it is for ""Tender No. 12/5054/07/12 – Construction of the New Cargo Gate Area in the Port of Haifa"" (The IPC shall be entitled to demand an extension of the period of this Bank Guarantee for a period of an additional six months). 4.3 The presentation by Israeli entities of all certificates, affidavits and approvals in accordance with the Transactions by Public Bodies (Enforcement of Keeping of Accounts) Law, 5736-1976. In the event that the Bidder which is awarded the Works is a non-Israeli entity, and as a condition precedent to the signing of the Contract with the non-Israeli entity, payments to that non-Israeli entity will be made through a local, Israeli, company which will be established by the non-Israeli entity. The local – Israeli – company must present all certificates, affidavits and approvals in accordance with the Transactions by Public Bodies (Enforcement of Keeping of Accounts) Law, 5736-1976. as a condition precedent to the signing of the contract with the non-Israeli entity 4.4 Proven experience of the Bidder, as a main contractor, in carrying out paving and area development projects, with at least two projects that were carried out since the year 2003 onward and completed, and which the payments for the performance of paving and area development works included in them were of at least 25,000,000 NIS for each such project. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax.) 4.5 The Bidder, or a subcontractor proposed by the Bidder for performance of the communication infrastructures, must meet all of the following conditions: 4.5.1 Registration with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the Tender, in Branch 240 – Laying of Communications Cables, of at least Classification ""Alef"" – 1. 4.5.2 Proven experience in the design, supply, installation and support of communications infrastructure projects, with at least two projects , since 2006 onwards with each one of them being of at least 1,000,000 NIS. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS is in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax.) 4.5.3 Possessing a valid and existing license for network termination points from the Ministry of Communications. 4.5.4 The Bidder, or a subcontractor proposed by the Bidder, for carrying out the electrical works must meet all of the following conditions: 4.5.4.1 Registration with the Registrar of Contractors of the Ministry of Construction and Housing, valid as of the last date for the submission of the Tender, in Branch 160 – Electrical Works, of Classification ""Alef"" – 5 (unlimited). 4.5.4.2 Proven experience performing electrical work at low voltages and high voltage and has performed, from 2006 onwards, at least one project of electrical work including low and high voltage works, amounting to at least 10 million NIS. (The amounts in this paragraph are in NIS in current prices and do not include Value Added Tax. 4.6 For the purpose of demonstrating the financial stability of the Bidder, the Bidder shall present a certification, from its bank, updated as of a date one month before the last date which has been fixed for presentation of the Tender, in accordance with the text set out in Document ""P"" of the Tender Documents. A Foreign Bidder may present a letter from an ""Approved bank"". A Bank letter which contains material changes in the text and which are not changes just in style, in accordance with the discretion of the Bid Committee, will not be accepted. 4.7 Participation in a Site Visit for potential Bidders/contractors that shall take place on27/8/2014 beginning at 10:00 and which will depart from the Port's club, at the security building, in the Haifa Port. Those interested in participating in the Site Visit must send a written request, no later than 20/8/2014 at 14:00 to Fax +972-3-5622173. The request must include the name(s) of the participant(s), their Identity Numbers or their Passport Number (with a copy of the relevant identification page(s) from their Passport) and the license plate number of the participant(s) car. For a further explanation with regard to the location of the conference and Site Visit, please contact the Project Manager, Engineer Chaim Ziv, at +972-52-329-0505. It is hereby emphasized that all Bidders must participate in the site visit. Only those Bidders who participated in the site visit will be permitted to submit their tenders for these Works. 5. The Tender Documents: 5.1 The Tender Documents, which are in Hebrew, can be reviewed , without charge, beginning on 12/8/2014, at the offices of the IPC, Menachem Begin Road 74, Tel Aviv, 10 th floor, Room 1003 on Sunday through Thursday, between the hours of 9:00 until 14:00. 5.2 The Tender Documents, which are in Hebrew, can be purchased at the offices mentioned in paragraph 5.1 and on the days and times set out therein, for the non-refundable sum of 1,500 NIS, including VAT which shall be paid to at the Treasurer's Office of the IPC 5.3 In addition to that which is set out in paragraph 5.2, a Potential Bidder which wants to participate in the Tender is required to pay to the IPC, before presenting its Tender, a participation fee of the non-refundable sum of 13,500 NIS, including VAT. This fee must be paid at the Treasurer's Department of the IPC or must be deposited in the bank account of the IPC at ""Bank Hapoalim"" Branch 063, Account no.7517. 6. For foreign Bidders, the above-mentioned sums in NIS shall be calculated on the basis of 4.8 NIS for 1 Euro or 3.5 NIS for 1 U.S. Dollar, except the amount of the Bid Security (Bid Bond). 7. Those interested in participating in the Tender must submit their Tenders in writing, with all the required documentation, in a sealed envelope, no later than 23/9/2014, at 12:00 in the Tender Box in the Offices of the IPC, 74 Menachem Begin Road, Tel Aviv, Israel, 10th floor, Room 1010. 8. The IPC is not obligated to accept the least expensive Tendered offer or any Tendered offer whatsoever. 9. Additional information can be received from the Head of the Construction Department of the IPC, TEL +972 - (3)-5657922, FAX +972 (3)-5616541. Those making inquiries by fax should request verification of the receipt of any such inquiries. 10. This advertisement does not contain all of the Tender Conditions. The entire and binding Tender Conditions appear in the Tender Documents. Thus, in the event of any discrepancy between this advertisement and the Tender Documents, that which is stated in the Tender Documents shall prevail . It is hereby clarified that the binding version of the Tender Documents are those in the Hebrew language. 11. All of a Bidder's expenses and costs, of any type whatsoever, which are connected with the preparation of and/or participation in the Tender, shall be borne by the Bidder only and, in any event, will not be returned to it. 12. Mandatory Business Cooperation A Foreign Bidder - in the event it wins the Tender – is obligated to provide Business Cooperation at a level of 35% of the Contract Price if it is an entity not from a Nation which is a party to the Agreement on Government Procurement (GPA) or at a level of 20% if it is an entity from a Nation which is a party to the GPA, all in accordance with the Mandatory Tenders Regulations (Preferences for Israel Products and Business Cooperation) 5755 – 1995, to the extent that the Regulations do not contradict the obligations of the State of Israel under any international treaty. 13. Conditions : It is brought to the attention of all Bidders that the performance of these works is subject to the precondition of the receipt of all appropriate permits and budgetary approvals and that all decisions about the winner of the Tender and/or contracting with that winning Bidder will be subject to the precondition, as above said, and will not enter into force unless these preconditions are met. The period of time for the carrying out of these preconditions will be up to 4 months after the date of the signing of a Contract with the winner of this Tender. Everyone presenting an offer in this Tender does it with knowledge of these preconditions and agrees to waive all claims with regard to these preconditions. Everyone presenting an offer agrees, in presenting its offer, that it has not obtained any rights in the event that a condition is not met and/or that it will not be possible to carry out the Works in accordance with this Tender (whether there has been a contract between the IPC and it or not), and that it will not be entitled to any damages or indemnification or return of sums whatsoever. In such an event, the contract which will be signed with the winner of the Tender will be a conditional contract subject to the receipt of all legally-required permits and authorizations. In any event, it is hereby emphasized that the contract between the IPC and the winning Bidder will enter into effect just if the above conditions are met.

Post Comments:
Please contact Charles Brown at US Embassy Tel Aviv for more information

Project Size (USD): 27144
Status: In Procurement

Description:
An open design contest for ideas design concept to arrange Paneriai Memorial to Victims of Holocaust and All Victims Nazism. The purpose of the new concept is to set principles for renovation and adaption of the Paneriai Memorial site for visitors’ needs by ensuring maximum preservation of the authentic features and minimal restoration of the lost constituents of the site, as well as to commemorate victims. A group of economic entities acting under a joint activity agreement can also make an entry; it is not required for a group of economic entities to be a legal person in order to make an entry. The project, which consists of the construction, operation and maintenance of two photovoltaic (PV) electric generation plants, CondorSolar, 30MW and SolarConnection, 20MW and their associated facilities, will be located in Tabacundo, in the province of Pichincha, Ecuador.

" DATATABLE.735,2014-03-30T22:36:24.032,2014-03-30T22:36:24.032,144.96327999999994,-37.814107,Australia,Melbourne,,Medibank Privatization,,Finance and Insurance,3000000000,"On March 26, 2014, the Australian government announced it would sell state-owned health insurance provider Medibank through an initial public offering (IPO). Medibank is Australia’s largest private health fund with 3.8 million members, accounting for 30% of the health insurance market. Estimates of Medibank’s value range from $3 billion to $6 billion. The IPO will take place in the 2014-15 financial year, from July 1, 2014 to June 30, 2015. The Medibank Private Sale Act of 2006 limits any one investor to no more than a 15% share in the insurer. The Australian government has called for tender submissions for up to four investment banks to act as joint lead managers of the IPO. Tenders must be lodged with the Australian Department of Finance by April 7 at 11am local time. Tender information is at the following link: https://www.tenders.gov.au/?event=public.atm.show&ATMUUID=DF66C2CA-A531-3329-A057F7EAD6722E5B. ",health insurance provider,Post Identified Project,2014-03-26,2014-04-07,Private,,Ministry of FInance,http://www.financeminister.gov.au/media/2014/mr_2014-18.html,"Medibank will be the first of several privatizations that the Government of Australia is expected to announce in 2014-15, and the Australian government has called for tender submissions for up to four investment banks to act as joint lead managers of the IPO. ","Matt Murray, Economic Counselor, Embassy Canberra",MurrayMD@state.gov,https://www.tenders.gov.au/?event=public.atm.show&ATMUUID=DF66C2CA-A531-3329-A057F7EAD6722E5B,http://canberra.usembassy.gov/business.html,,,1,In Procurement,0,POINT (16137238.513322733 -4553198.5474677),"
Medibank Privatization
Country: Australia
Sector: Finance and Insurance
Date Added: 2014-03-30
Primary Funding Source: Private
Project Size (USD): 3000000000
Status: In Procurement

Description:
On March 26, 2014, the Australian government announced it would sell state-owned health insurance provider Medibank through an initial public offering (IPO). Medibank is Australia’s largest private health fund with 3.8 million members, accounting for 30% of the health insurance market. Estimates of Medibank’s value range from $3 billion to $6 billion. The IPO will take place in the 2014-15 financial year, from July 1, 2014 to June 30, 2015. The Medibank Private Sale Act of 2006 limits any one investor to no more than a 15% share in the insurer. The Australian government has called for tender submissions for up to four investment banks to act as joint lead managers of the IPO. Tenders must be lodged with the Australian Department of Finance by April 7 at 11am local time. Tender information is at the following link: https://www.tenders.gov.au/?event=public.atm.show&ATMUUID=DF66C2CA-A531-3329-A057F7EAD6722E5B. The Minister for Finance’s press release on the privatization of Medibank can be found at the following link: http://www.financeminister.gov.au/media/2014/mr_2014-18.html.

Post Comments:
Medibank will be the first of several privatizations that the Government of Australia is expected to announce in 2014-15, and the Australian government has called for tender submissions for up to four investment banks to act as joint lead managers of the IPO.

" DATATABLE.956,2014-09-25T02:28:45.882,2014-09-25T02:28:45.882,133.77513599999997,-25.274398,Australia,South Australia/green triangle region,,Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan ,,Construction,300060000," The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan was released in April 2009 to secure multi million dollar trade and employment opportunities in the Green Triangle region. The plan is endorsed by both the Victorian and South Australian governments, local governments and major industry and transport organisations operating within the Green Triangle region. There is an estimated $8.7 billion worth of private investment set to commence within the Green Triangle region over the next five years in the mining, timber, energy, agriculture and dairy industries. It is critical that the right infrastructure exists for communities to benefit from this export driven growth and the job opportunities that it creates. Many of the new investments will be in new and emerging sectors including low emissions thermal power, wave energy and natural gas - helping to strengthen the region’s economy in a carbon constrained future. The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan outlines the significant export and employment opportunities in the region over the next decade and beyond and the need for infrastructure upgrades to the value of $340 million to accommodate the growing freight task. The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan identifies critical strategic actions required to accommodate freight export growth in the areas of: • Road network enhancements • Rail network enhancements • Regulatory reform • Job opportunities and skills training • Community development Transport infrastructure and port handling facilities upgrades are critical to the implementation of this plan. Federal government funding is required for these national building projects. The new investments scheduled for the region will generate 5,400 construction jobs and up to 1,000 direct jobs in the blue gum timber industry alone, with a further 1,000 additional jobs in industry associated with the timber industry. Blue gum wood chip exports through the Port of Portland will double, the $34 million South West Fibre static chip mill at Myamyn has commenced chipping operations and the Plantation Energy biofuel plant is due for construction at Heywood during 2010. Key export markets in the region include: • 25% of Australia’s dairy product • 17% of Australia’s plantation, forestry and wood processing • Significant heavy mineral exploration within the Murray Basin • 1 million tons of annual grain exports through the Port of Portland • 67,000 tons of livestock exports through the Port of Portland • Major industry exporting from the Port of Portland including Portland Aluminium (Victoria’s largest exporter by dollar value) With trade volumes through the Port of Portland projected to double to 7 million tons over the next five to ten years, the Port of Portland will become Australia’s largest wood chip export port. Increased exports will require an additional 75 ships through the port each year. This export growth (the port currently delivers $1.5 billion annually into the regional economy) will be a significant economic driver for the region. ","infrastructure, freights",Post Identified Project,,,Government,,Victoria and South Australia Government,sburdack@glenelg.vic.gov.au (03) 5522 2218,,Vanessa Colon,colonvd@state.gov,http://www.thinkingtransport.org.au/matrix/glenelg-shire-council/green-triangle-region-freight-action-plan ,,,,1,Pipeline,0,POINT (14891780.020320917 -2909486.0549970693),"
Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan
Country: Australia
Sector: Construction
Date Added: 2014-09-25
Primary Funding Source: Government
Project Size (USD): 300060000
Status: Pipeline

Description:
The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan was released in April 2009 to secure multi million dollar trade and employment opportunities in the Green Triangle region. The plan is endorsed by both the Victorian and South Australian governments, local governments and major industry and transport organisations operating within the Green Triangle region. There is an estimated $8.7 billion worth of private investment set to commence within the Green Triangle region over the next five years in the mining, timber, energy, agriculture and dairy industries. It is critical that the right infrastructure exists for communities to benefit from this export driven growth and the job opportunities that it creates. Many of the new investments will be in new and emerging sectors including low emissions thermal power, wave energy and natural gas - helping to strengthen the region’s economy in a carbon constrained future. The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan outlines the significant export and employment opportunities in the region over the next decade and beyond and the need for infrastructure upgrades to the value of $340 million to accommodate the growing freight task. The Green Triangle Region Freight Action Plan identifies critical strategic actions required to accommodate freight export growth in the areas of: • Road network enhancements • Rail network enhancements • Regulatory reform • Job opportunities and skills training • Community development Transport infrastructure and port handling facilities upgrades are critical to the implementation of this plan. Federal government funding is required for these national building projects. The new investments scheduled for the region will generate 5,400 construction jobs and up to 1,000 direct jobs in the blue gum timber industry alone, with a further 1,000 additional jobs in industry associated with the timber industry. Blue gum wood chip exports through the Port of Portland will double, the $34 million South West Fibre static chip mill at Myamyn has commenced chipping operations and the Plantation Energy biofuel plant is due for construction at Heywood during 2010. Key export markets in the region include: • 25% of Australia’s dairy product • 17% of Australia’s plantation, forestry and wood processing • Significant heavy mineral exploration within the Murray Basin • 1 million tons of annual grain exports through the Port of Portland • 67,000 tons of livestock exports through the Port of Portland • Major industry exporting from the Port of Portland including Portland Aluminium (Victoria’s largest exporter by dollar value) With trade volumes through the Port of Portland projected to double to 7 million tons over the next five to ten years, the Port of Portland will become Australia’s largest wood chip export port. Increased exports will require an additional 75 ships through the port each year. This export growth (the port currently delivers $1.5 billion annually into the regional economy) will be a significant economic driver for the region.

Project Website   Contact

" DATATABLE.651,2014-02-20T15:18:35.105,2014-02-20T15:18:35.105,-72.285215,18.971187,Haiti,Haiti,,Institutional Strengthening and Reform of the Transport Sector I,HA-L1088,Public Administration,12000000,"The proposed program is the first of three programmatic policy based grants (PBGs), to support the Government of Haiti (GoH) to design and implement policy, legal and institutional reforms in the transport sector. Those reforms will address the policy, legal and institutional constraints that negatively affect the effective and sustainable implementation, output delivery and impact of the IDB-financed investment operations currently under execution and expected for the following years in the transport sector.",Public Administration; Transportation; Policy; Law; Finance,Inter-American Development Bank,2013-10-01,,Development Banks,Republic of Haiti,Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF),"FIORAVANTI, REINALDO DANIEL - Inter-American Development Bank",,"Asike, Chuka",AsikeC@state.gov,"http://www.iadb.org/en/projects/project-description-title,1303.html?id=HA-L1088",http://haiti.usembassy.gov/business.html,,,1,Pipeline,1,POINT (-8046753.325682299 2151543.9447495816),"
Institutional Strengthening and Reform of the Transport Sector I
Country: Haiti
Sector: Public Administration
Date Added: 2014-02-20
Primary Funding Source: Development Banks
Project Size (USD): 12000000
Status: Pipeline

Archived: Yes
Description:
The proposed program is the first of three programmatic policy based grants (PBGs), to support the Government of Haiti (GoH) to design and implement policy, legal and institutional reforms in the transport sector. Those reforms will address the policy, legal and institutional constraints that negatively affect the effective and sustainable implementation, output delivery and impact of the IDB-financed investment operations currently under execution and expected for the following years in the transport sector.

Project Website   Embassy Website   Contact
" DATATABLE.490,2014-02-10T10:14:46.476,2014-02-10T10:14:46.476,8.966666700000019,36.6166667,Tunisia,Bousalem,,Highway Bousalem – Algerian border,,Construction,1800000,"The project aims to expand the highway A3 to the Algerian border by building the link between Bousalem and the Algerian border. This project goes with the framework of the Maghreb highways network, which aims to strengthen the link between the Maghreb countries and support trade exchanges and enhance economic integration and synergy. The project will improve accessibility between key development areas and the capital as well as the major urban poles And increases the competitiveness of the economic institutions implemented alongside the highway. The project will improve and secure the conditions of user’s movement between Bousalem and the Tunisian-Algerian border, including increased travel speed, lowering the generalized transport costs and reducing the number of accidents traffic on this route Project owner: Ministry of Equipment and Environment Project scope: the length of the highway from Bousalem to the Algerian border is estimated to 80 km. The project also includes engineering works for the construction of the road, interchange bridges, building technical facilities and other facilities such as tunnels, water facilities and payment gates. Project cost: the cost of the works is estimated to 1,200 MTND basis on 15 MTND per km related to geophysics of lands crossed by the highway track. Project implementation status: - The project is at the stage of preparation of preliminary studies; - It should be pointed out that there was close coordination with the Algerian counterparts to ensure the Tunisian and Algerian highways are connected and that they meet at the international transit point. Financing studies: - The Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development contributed to finance monitoring, follow-up and technical supervision of the studies for the highrway Bousalem – Algerian border with a donation worth of KD 300 thousand. - Monitoring, follow-up and technical supervision of the studies for the highway Bousalem – Algerian border aim to assist the administration in ensuring the quality of the study by supervising and controlling all the stages of the study, preparing the financial analyses for the financing alternatives of the works, preparing the documents relating to the public consultation about the project, and building capacity of engineers of the public department of highway engineering. ",highway,Post Identified Project,2013-10-31,2013-10-31,Government,Ministry of Equipment and Environment,Ministry of Equipment and Environment,"Address: Avenue Habib Chrita - Cité Jardins - 1002 Tunis Belvédère, Tunisia - Phone : (+216) 71 842 244 Fax : (+216) 71 840 495 e-mail : brc@mehat.gov.tn Website: http://www.equipement.tn","For more information about the status of the project, please email us.",Hanen Ltifi,ltifiH@state.gov,http://www.investintunisia.tn/document/701.pdf,http://tunisia.usembassy.gov/business.html,,,1,Pipeline,0,POINT (998164.7711570046 4385808.912280733),"
Highway Bousalem – Algerian border
Country: Tunisia
Sector: Construction
Date Added: 2014-02-10
Primary Funding Source: Government
Project Size (USD): 1800000
Status: Pipeline

Description:
The project aims to expand the highway A3 to the Algerian border by building the link between Bousalem and the Algerian border. This project goes with the framework of the Maghreb highways network, which aims to strengthen the link between the Maghreb countries and support trade exchanges and enhance economic integration and synergy. The project will improve accessibility between key development areas and the capital as well as the major urban poles And increases the competitiveness of the economic institutions implemented alongside the highway. The project will improve and secure the conditions of user’s movement between Bousalem and the Tunisian-Algerian border, including increased travel speed, lowering the generalized transport costs and reducing the number of accidents traffic on this route Project owner: Ministry of Equipment and Environment Project scope: the length of the highway from Bousalem to the Algerian border is estimated to 80 km. The project also includes engineering works for the construction of the road, interchange bridges, building technical facilities and other facilities such as tunnels, water facilities and payment gates. Project cost: the cost of the works is estimated to 1,200 MTND basis on 15 MTND per km related to geophysics of lands crossed by the highway track. Project implementation status: - The project is at the stage of preparation of preliminary studies; - It should be pointed out that there was close coordination with the Algerian counterparts to ensure the Tunisian and Algerian highways are connected and that they meet at the international transit point. Financing studies: - The Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development contributed to finance monitoring, follow-up and technical supervision of the studies for the highrway Bousalem – Algerian border with a donation worth of KD 300 thousand. - Monitoring, follow-up and technical supervision of the studies for the highway Bousalem – Algerian border aim to assist the administration in ensuring the quality of the study by supervising and controlling all the stages of the study, preparing the financial analyses for the financing alternatives of the works, preparing the documents relating to the public consultation about the project, and building capacity of engineers of the public department of highway engineering.

Post Comments:
For more information about the status of the project, please email us.

Project Website   Embassy Website   Contact

",Finance,Inter-American Development Bank,,,Development Banks,,Central Reserve Bank of EL Salvador,,,Chuka Asike,Asikec@state.gov,,,,,1,Pipeline,1,POINT (-9895916.452888966 1550614.4485089574),"
Contingent Credit Line for Sustainable Development
Country: El Salvador
Sector: Finance and Insurance
Date Added: 2014-02-20
Primary Funding Source: Development Banks
Project Size (USD): 100000000
Status: Pipeline

Archived: Yes
Description:
A line of credit, understood as contingent resources available that can provide financial institutions in specific situations, serves as a transitional step to the establishment of FL and constitutes a support to the BCR in its power to Lender of Last Instance mitigating effect of reduction in credit growth and higher cost.

Contact
